Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: A Cyber-Physical Infrastructure for the "Smart City"

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims at making cities "smarter" by engineering processes such as traffic control, efficient parking services, and new urban activities such as recharging electric vehicles. To that end, the research will study the components needed to establish a Cyber-Physical Infrastructure for urban environments and address fundamental problems that involve data collection, resource allocation, real-time decision making, safety, and security. Accordingly, the research is organized along two main directions: (i) Sensing and data acquisition using a new mobile sensor network paradigm designed for urban environments; and (ii) Decision Support for the "Smart City" relying on formal verification and certification methods coupled with innovative dynamic optimization techniques used for decision making and resource allocation. The work will bring together and build upon methodological advances in optimization under uncertainty, computer simulation, discrete event and hybrid systems, control and games, system security, and formal verification and safety. Target applications include: a "Smart Parking" system where parking spaces are optimally assigned and reserved, and vehicular traffic regulation.

The research has the potential of revolutionizing the way cities are viewed: from a passive living and working environment to a highly dynamic one with new ways to deal with transportation, energy, and safety. Teaming up with stakeholders in the Boston Back Bay neighborhood, the City of Boston, and private industry, the research team expects to establish new collaborative models between universities and urban groups for cutting-edge research embedded in the deployment of an exciting technological, economic, and sociological development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated various methods for system monitoring, status tracking, and performance prediction under uncertainty. This contributes to the overall objective of the project, which is to make cities, viewed as a dynamic and cyber-physical system, "smarter".  

Intellectual contributions include both analytical and experimental work on stochastic modeling based on particle filter and total variation filter, for fault detection and system state evolution tracking with both time-varying gradual changes and abrupt, transient occurrence. The developed algorithms were evaluated in scenarios such as occupancy-based temperature control in buildings for improved energy-efficiency in building climate control, which is an integral component of a smart city. Furthermore, a new, spatial correlation-based method for evaluating the trustworthiness of measurements performed by sensor networks with distributed homogeneous and/or non-homogeneous sensors was developed, which enabled identification of defective sensors and improved reliability in system monitoring.

Outcome of this research has been reflected in multiple papers that were published or under review by high impact technical journals. One the papers received the Best Student Paper Award from an IEEE International Conference in 2015. Furthermore, the PI gave multiple seminars at universities in the US, UK, and China, as well keynote speeches at international conferences sponsored by technical societies in the areas of electrical and computer engineering (such as IEEE) and mechanical/manufacturing engineering (such as CIRP).

The broader impact of this research lies in the ability of the developed methods in sensing self-diagnosis and dynamical event tracking. As an example, since the trustworthiness evaluation method was developed based on either geometric information or multivariate data fusion, the method is suitable for applications where: a) sensors are spatially distributed; b) no explicit relationship between the measured quantity and the state to be estimated is known; and c) sensor reading is affected by both sensor status and variability of the measured quantity.  These are characteristic of cities that can be viewed as a highly dynamic and nonlinear environment requiring a large number of sensors for status monitoring, operation control, and resource allocation optimization.
